message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest rheumatoid arthritis, which is strongly associated with HLA-DR4. HLA-B27 is associated with ankylosing spondylitis, HLA-DR2 is associated with multiple sclerosis, and HLA-DR3 is associated with Sjögren syndrome and systemic lupus erythematosus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The progressive joint pain, symmetrical swelling of the MCP joints, and weight loss suggest Rheumatoid arthritis, which is strongly associated with the HLA-DR4 genotype. HLA-B27 is associated with ankylosing spondylitis, HLA-DR2 is associated with multiple sclerosis, and HLA-DR3 is associated with autoimmune hepatitis. None of these conditions match the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with joint pain that is worse around her knuckles, symmetric swelling of the metacarpophalangeal joints, and weight loss. These are all symptoms commonly seen in rheumatoid arthritis (RA). HLA-DR4 is a known genetic risk factor for RA, while the other options are associated with different autoimmune diseases.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest rheumatoid arthritis (RA), which is most strongly associated with HLA-DR4. Swollen metacarpophalangeal joints are a classic sign of RA, and the patient’s morning stiffness and weight loss are also common symptoms. HLA-B27 is associated with ankylosing spondylitis, HLA-DR2 is associated with multiple sclerosis, and HLA-DR3 is associated with systemic lupus erythematosus. None of these conditions would explain the patient’s symptoms as well as RA.
